A&yogh;en þat folk ouer wícke feoloun&slong; Horstmann wonders whether "spac he" should be added to "a&yogh;en that folk" or whether "a&yogh;en that folk" references "damagingue". Alternatively, he suggests tat "ouer" might be read as "your" if the first letter is an "e" with a weakly visible stroke. As I read it, "a&yogh;en that folk" does refer back to "damagingue", and the Jesus' speech begins immediately after. Horstmann's reading of "o" as "e" is plausible given the letter's shape, but perhaps reading the meaning of the phrase as "ever-wicked felons" makes more sense than "your wicked felons".
